review_title: Ok before covid - much worse after

pros: Good location if you’re from the surrounding area and don’t want to commute
cons:
Terrible management, not supportive, makes it very obvious that you are replaceable and “just a body”
Severely understaffed ER
Puts your nursing license at risk every time you work
Inexperienced nurses outnumber experienced nurses. On any given night there will only be new grads working
Staff is rude, lazy, and will talk bad about every one that works there 
Under payed compared to surrounding hospitals
Zero diversity or inclusion at this hospital

Other units may be better, but do not work in the ER.

pros: With the staffing shortage, there is ample opportunity to make a lot of extra money by picking up shifts. Was just recently given a salary adjustment per market worth
cons: Too busy to give quality patient care that I desire. Too much redundancy when documenting. Difficult to take desired time off during the summer and need to request time off at least 6-8 weeks in advance.

pros: The resource nurses on night shift were always helpful and just a page away
cons:
Impossible assignments. 6 patient per nurse ratio on nights (which is unfortunately the norm) but the acuity was awful. At least 4 of these patients couldn’t go to the bathroom on their own and there was only one (sometimes zero) tech to help. I spent most of my shifts giving meds and helping people go to the bathroom. 

I caught COVID 19 from a patient that should have been in the ICU. I was a new grad on a med surg floor. We had to share PPE. I had a preceptor with this patient but the preceptor went into the room maybe once during this shift which left me with the patient alone while she continuously coughed and spit meds in my face. This preceptor intentionally avoided going into the room. One of her excuses was she had to get food from the cafeteria before it closed. I came down with symptoms less than 2 weeks later and missed 4 weeks of work because I was so sick. I only got paid for 2 of those weeks. I wasn’t protected by my employer and then they refused to pay me for my time out by something they caused. My depression declined rapidly after having COVID and there were signs through out the hospital for mental health help for employees. I called 3 times and left messages and never got a call back. 

Also as soon as i got off orientation I got floated....as a new nurse......kind of messed up.

pros: Working with the patients was the best part
cons: The laboratory staff and overall hospital staff were mean and nasty! Everyone throughout the hospital complained about them specifically the phlebotomy staff and supervisors. The older phlebotomy staff bullies the new phlebotomist and the managers say nothing about it!

pros: Commitment to caring for patients and health in the community.  Transparency is actually pretty good, but only some of the time, when the President holds quarterly conferences with all staff members (the hospital newsletter does have info about other departments and groups, but not the organizational whole).
cons: Seems to be a massive breakdown between staffing Needs and management Wants which does put many patients at risk too often. "Treat everyone from CEO to the janitor with the same respect" doesn't apply here: doctors can be as admonishing and scornful and disrespectful as often as they want towards staff and get away with it. Doctors should never be treated like royalty, anywhere, period! We all work here together, we should all be treated equally together.

pros: Nothing positive, run from this place. Do not be associated with a place like this.
cons: I would never recommend this hospital to anyone. The staff need to be trained on basic customer service and compassion for patients. The nurses are racist. If you are black, you need to go somewhere else. They act like the KKK. Stay away. One nurse even filed a complaint against a mentally challenged patient because the patient pushed her. Who does that? A patient that was disoriented on the heavy meds that was pumped into her.  The racist nurse filed a complaint with the local police station asking for the patient to be arrested after leaving the hospital. I hate to think what that racist nurse did to that vulnerable young adult when there was nobody around. She should be arrested. She should not be in the nursing field. She needs to be fired. She has no compassion.

job_title: IS Information Worker in Westminster, MD
pros: Great associate environment to work at, high level of professionalism among associates, typically very easy working hours with flexible time for most individuals. Supportive administration toward technical projects, and good cooperation of staff to meet deadlines and goals. Advancement from within is typically promoted. Challenging work environment with varying responsibilities and disciplines to become involved with. It is a friendly atmosphere and is a place where you can make a difference in the advancement of healthcare.
cons: The healthcare software systems vendor support is lackluster and the EMR is tough to learn and navigate. On the job learning is definitely required. There isn't much else in the way of healthcare systems training, and outside learning from vendor services is essentially non-existent, so learning hands-on is an absolute requirement. Management often does not relay team goals effectively to daily staff, which means initiatives are not fully understood. Work is often sent to outside contractors rather than hiring additional internal staff. This causes problems because new contractors usually do not understand the underlying systems in use, and often do not understand the politics of the environment. The heavy use of temporary contractors to handle workloads is an issue because contractors often do not have necessary underlying knowledge of the storage/technical and various independent medical systems which are not always interfaced or integrated. Employees are often placed in the position of training contractors who typically do not share their documentation of the work being done causing discrepancies in systems documentation. Employees must continue to run their own concurrent workloads during these high volume times - while often being paid (often about 1/3rd) of the received pay of the contractor grade pay.

pros: Community hospital atmosphere. Many people have worked there for years and years, so you work along the same individuals for a long period of time and get to know everyone well. The patients in general are a good population to work with. They have a great tuition reimbursement plan to further your education. The CEO is former RN at the hospital who has worked her way through leadership roles to CEO. It is inspiring to see her advancement and there is definitely room for growth within the organization. The recent merge with lifebridge health has brought a lot of changes but most of them are a direct improvement for the patients ( i.e. New services, specialties, offering more to the community) and for the employees with improved benefits, increased tuition reimbursement. More money for work place events/activities to boost staff morale.
cons: There is a lot of favoritism. Unfortunately that means that sometimes the wrong people get moved into positions of leadership or middle management just because they have been with the organization a long time, or are socially connected well. Not everyone who has been a nurse for 10 years, is well suited for management just because they have been with the company for a while. I think that has gotten the management situation into trouble, but now that they have merged with lifebridge there has been a lot of adjustments to the leadership team. Understaffing is an issue, you get pulled often to other units leaving yours short and you seem to be treated unfairly on other units and get the worst assignment while there.  In addition, there is a lot of talking behind other people's backs, people act friendly to you and then talk about you poorly when your not there. Your nursing judgement and interventions or lack there of is always on the chopping block for evaluation by other nurses who think you should have done differently. My orientation as a brand new nurse years ago, was very challenging. I left many days in tears and wanted to quit because the senior nurses were so harsh with me and judge mental. The CEO is great-- but I think a negative is that she has 4 immediate family members working in various departments around the hospital and they are treated above the others by their direct supervisors and a direct source of information to their mother. Which sometimes is a good thing and makes way for changes, but other times is not.
